abstract.p: Letter from Richard Motta, president and CEO, Volunteers of America-Greater New York, says merchants of Madison Avenue should band together and work with city and nonprofit providers to help chronically homeless make transition from streets to shelters and permanent homes instead of filing suits (Jan 18 article)

block.p: Re ''Antique Dealer Sues to Bar Homeless From Sidewalk'' (news article, Jan. 18): The merchants of Madison Avenue would do better to band together and work with New York City and nonprofit providers in coordinated action to help the chronically homeless make the transition off the streets and into shelters and permanent homes.

Re ''Antique Dealer Sues to Bar Homeless From Sidewalk'' (news article, Jan. 18): The merchants of Madison Avenue would do better to band together and work with New York City and nonprofit providers in coordinated action to help the chronically homeless make the transition off the streets and into shelters and permanent homes.

While suing may draw temporary attention to the matter, it will hardly provide permanent relief for residents, business owners or the homeless, who need patience, treatment and a roof over their heads, not time in front of a judge.
Richard Motta President and C.E.O., Volunteers of America-Greater New York New York, Jan. 22, 2007
